item.title: 'How Is Shouting 'Jai Sriram' Inside Mosque An Offence?' : Supreme Court Asks Complainant, Seeks... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
How Is Shouting 'Jai Sriram' Inside Mosque An Offence?' : Supreme Court Asks Complainant, Seeks...

Date: December 16, 2023

Source: Supreme Court

The Supreme Court sought the stand of the State of Karnataka in a petition challenging the Karnataka High Court's view that shouting 'Jai Sriram' inside a mosque would not amount to an offence.

  1. The Supreme Court bench, consisting of Justices Pankaj Mithal and Sandeep Mehta, is hearing a petition against the Karnataka High Court's judgment.
  2. The High Court had quashed criminal proceedings against two persons accused of trespassing in a mosque and shouting 'Jai Sriram'.
  3. Senior Advocate Devadatt Kamat, representing the complainant, argued that shouting a religious slogan in another religious place would amount to inciting communal disharmony.
  4. The bench questioned whether merely being near the mosque would mean the accused shouted the slogans.
  5. Kamat clarified that the complainant is only the caretaker of the mosque and it is the police's responsibility to investigate and collect evidence.
The High Court observed, 'It is un-understandable as to how if someone shouts 'Jai Sriram' it would outrage the religious feeling of any class'.

The bench directed the petitioner to serve a copy of the petition on the State of Karnataka, with the matter to be posted next in January 2025.

Congress Reacts After Omar Abdullah Junks Opposition's EVM Charge

Publication Date: December 16, 2024   Source: NDTV

The Congress party has criticized ally Omar Abdullah's stance on opposition issues, particularly regarding recent allegations of manipulation of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs), after Abdullah dismissed these claims.

  • Omar Abdullah's party, the National Conference, contested the Jammu and Kashmir elections alongside the Congress.
  • Congress parliamentarian Manickam Tagore highlighted differing views on EVMs among opposition parties following recent elections.
  • Recent opposition claims regarding EVM discrepancies were led by Sharad Pawar's NCP and Shiv Sena (UBT).
  • Congress's Working Committee has accused the Election Commission of partisan conduct and hinted at targeted manipulation.
  • Abdullah stated that political parties doubting EVMs should refrain from participating in elections.
Mr. Abdullah stated, "When you get a hundred plus members of parliament using the same EVMs, and you celebrate that... you can't... turn around and say... we don't like these EVMs because now the election results aren't going the way we would like them to."

The debate over EVM integrity showcases significant differences within the opposition and raises questions about electoral processes in India.

The court’s ruling not only addresses the specific case concerning Ankush Vipan Kapoor but also emphasizes the broader implications of substance abuse on society.

Coldwave conditions continue to grip Delhi, with a recorded minimum temperature of 4.5°C, marking the joint lowest this season.

  • Shallow fog resulted in visibility of around 800 metres.
  • Air quality index (AQI) reached 'very poor' levels, averaging 351.
  • Experts link the deterioration in AQI to a drop in wind speed; similar conditions expected to persist.
  • Lowest minimum temperature was recorded at 3.5°C in Pusa and 4°C in Ayanagar.
“A feeble western disturbance is beginning to impact northwest India, which is slowing down winds. This should keep the AQI likely in the very poor range.” - Mahesh Palawat, Skymet

The coldwave is set to continue, with temperatures predicted to hover around 5°C on Tuesday.

item.title: India can’t see ‘One Nation, One Election’ before 2034. Here’s what Modi govt is proposing - ThePrint
item.description:
India can't see ‘One Nation, One Election’ before 2034. Here’s what Modi govt is proposing

Publication Date: [Insert Date] Source: ThePrint

The BJP-led NDA government is set to introduce two significant bills aimed at achieving simultaneous elections for Lok Sabha and state assemblies. This move represents a critical step towards fulfilling a major electoral promise by the ruling party.

  • The Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty-Ninth Amendment Bill) and the Union Territories Law (Amendment) Bill are expected to be introduced in Lok Sabha soon.
  • These bills propose amendments to existing articles in the Constitution, enabling simultaneous elections.
  • The anticipated implementation date for 'One Nation, One Election' is projected to be 2034.
  • The bills will not require ratification by half of the state assemblies due to their constitutionality.
  • The government asserts that simultaneous elections will save costs and reduce disruptions caused by prolonged electoral cycles.
The ECI has pegged the cost of holding simultaneous elections at Rs 4,500 crore.

The introduction of these bills is part of a broader effort to streamline election processes across India, though the timeline for actual implementation remains several years away.

item.title: India already has 1.45 billion people. Why does it want more children? - BBC.com
item.description:
India: Why a nation of 1.45 billion wants more children

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: BBC

India's population has surpassed China's, leading to a renewed call for having more children, particularly from southern states like Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, which face low fertility rates and ageing populations.

  • India became the world's most populous country with 1.45 billion people.
  • Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu are advocating for higher birth rates due to declining fertility.
  • The country's fertility rate has dropped significantly from 5.7 births per woman in 1950 to 2 currently.
  • Some southern states maintain fertility rates below the replacement level, raising concerns about political representation.
  • The impending delimitation of electoral seats in 2026 could disadvantage economically prosperous southern states.
  • Demographers warn India's rapid ageing due to declining fertility rates may have economic and social implications.
  • Leaders, including Modi, suggest any changes to fiscal allocations will be considered carefully.
  • Experts stress the need for policies that enhance productivity and support a growing elderly population.
"India is getting old before getting rich." - Srinivas Goli

In conclusion, as India's demographics shift dramatically, the focus on increasing birth rates comes amid fears of economic strains and reduced political influence for certain regions.

item.description:
Vijay Diwas 2024: India, Bangladesh 1971 war veterans’ exchange visit to mark Vijay Diwas

Published on: December 16, 2024 05:34 am IST

Source: The Hindu

Eight Indian military veterans of Bangladesh’s 1971 Liberation War arrived in Dhaka, while eight officers from the Bangladesh Army reached Kolkata to join the Vijay Diwas celebrations occurring in both countries.

  • The delegation included two serving officers from both nations.
  • The Bangladesh delegation is composed of Mukti Jodhas, significant for their role in the resistance during the war.
  • There are ongoing strains related to violence against minority communities in Bangladesh.
  • This event symbolizes the friendship formed during the 1971 war.
  • Both countries celebrate their victory over Pakistan every year on December 16.
  • The annual visits aim to strengthen ties and remember shared sacrifices during the Liberation War.
“The exchange of veterans’ visits is a reminder of friendship forged in 1971,” - Political Analyst

The annual celebrations not only reflect the historical significance but also aim to ease current tensions between India and Bangladesh, showcasing goodwill for future relations.
